textModule.text: Activity: Mark the type of situation (threatening – T or beneficial – B) in which the reactions of the particular organs would occur. Then choose the division of the autonomic nervous system that is involved in this action.

Opposing Actions
of the Divisions of the ANS
Opposing Action of the Two Divisions of the Autonomic Nervous System

The two divisions of the autonomic nervous system are designed to work in opposition (or antagonistically) to each other. Every organ innervated by these systems is supplied by two sets of completely separate nerves, which transmit impulses that produce opposite effects.
Dilation of the pupil of the eye. {{1:sympathetic division|parasympathetic division}}

properties.property: The proper functioning of the internal organs and blood vessels is controlled by the autonomic nervous system (or ANS) [A.N.S.]). The ANS can be divided into the sympathetic division [pauze] and the parasympathetic division. These divisions are designed to work in opposition to each other. This means that, while the sympathetic division of the ANS stimulates secretion in a gland, the parasympathetic division inhibits it. Likewise, while the sympathetic division makes a muscle contract, the parasympathetic division makes it relax. The net effect depends on which division of the ANS has the stronger effect. The balance is regulated via the central nervous system on the basis of stimuli received from the external and internal environments. As a general rule, the sympathetic division of the ANS is recognized as being linked to self-defense and instant reactions to stressful situations. This kind of reaction is sometimes called the fight-or-flight response. On the other hand, the parasympathetic division is linked to the enhancement of normal activities when the body is at rest and the environment is quiet and beneficial.

textModule.text: Enhanced gastric gland secretion. {{1:parasympathetic division|sympathetic division}}
Increase in heart rate. {{1:sympathetic division|parasympathetic division}}
Contraction (decrease in diameter) of the bronchi. {{1:parasympathetic division|sympathetic division}}

properties.property:
Item1
In a threatening situation, the body requires more data about the surroundings. Therefore, the pupil dilates so that the eye may notice more details for use in attack or self-defense.
Item2
In a beneficial situation, the pupil contracts , restricting the amount of light entering the eye so that visual sensations do not disturb the resting process.
item3
In a threatening situation, the whole body becomes focused on acquiring strength for attack or self-defense. Digestion is less important, so the process is inhibited so that the energy that it requires can be diverted elsewhere.
Item4
In a beneficial situation, digestion is highly desirable because it is a process that promotes regeneration of the body's strength.
Item5
In a threatening situation, the body requires a greater supply of oxygen and nutrients. Therefore, the heart starts to pump the blood more quickly, so that these substances can be more effectively transported in the bloodstream.
Item6
In a beneficial situation, the body does not require large amounts of oxygen and nutrients. Therefore the heart rate can be slower.
Item7
In a threatening situation, the body requires a greater amount of oxygen and produces a greater amount of carbon dioxide. Therefore, the breathing becomes faster and the diameter of the bronchi increases in order to fulfill these requirements.
Item8
In a beneficial situation, the amount of oxygen required and the amount of carbon dioxide produced are not very high. Therefore, breathing can be slow and the diameter of the bronchi decreases.
